children.name: eat
children.definition: ăn
examples: Don’t eat so fast - you’ll get sick.
I’m so full. I couldn’t eat another thing.
She was sitting on the wall, eating an apple.
Hey! - Someone’s eaten all my chocolates.

children.name: have
children.definition: to eat a particular thing:ăn
examples: I wasn’t very hungry, so I just had a sandwich.
I think I’ll just have one more piece of cake.
have sth for lunch/dinner/breakfast
What shall we have for dinner?
I usually just have fruit for breakfast.

children.name: feed
children.definition: if animals or babies feed, they eat or drink:
examples: Most new babies will want to feed every few hours.
The pigs were feeding from a trough in the middle of the yard.
feed on
The larvae feed on the young shoots of water-lilies.

children.name: tuck in
children.definition: dig in/  informal to eat eagerly and with enjoyment: ăn ngon lành, chén say sưa
examples: Dinner’s ready everyone. Dig in!
Nick was already at the table, tucking in.
tuck into
‘This is delicious!’ he said, tucking into his steak and kidney pudding.

children.name: chow down
children.definition: US informal to eat, especially in a noisy way or in a way that shows you are very hungry:ăn say sưa
examples: We each grabbed a container of ice cream and chowed down.
chow down on
The kids were chowing down on a large pizza.

children.name: having eaten enough or too much food
have had enough
children.definition: to have eaten enough food, so that you do not want any more:ăn đủ rồi, ăn no rồi
examples: ‘Would you like some dessert?’ ‘No thanks, I’ve had enough.’
Leave the rest if you’ve had enough.

children.name: couldn’t eat another thing
children.definition: you say I couldn’t eat another thing when you have eaten a lot, especially because you enjoyed the food, and are very full:không thể ăn thêm gì
examples: The apple pie is delicious, but I won’t have another slice - I couldn’t eat another thing.

children.name: be full
children.definition: spokenif you are full, you have eaten so much food that you cannot eat any more:no
examples: ‘Would you like some more pie?’ ‘No thanks, I’m full.’
No more cake for me, thanks, I'm full.

children.name: bloated
children.definition: having eaten so much that your stomach feels very full and uncomfortable:đầy bụng
examples: I feel really bloated. I wish I hadn’t eaten so much.
bloated with
He fell onto the sofa, his stomach bloated with food.

children.name: on a full stomach
children.definition: if you do sth on a full stomach, you do it soon after eating a meal, when you are still feeling full:sau khi ăn no
examples: It isn’t wise to go swimming on a full stomach.
Never go swimming on a full stomach.

children.name: to stop eating or refuse to eat
fast
children.definition: to stop eating food for a fixed period of time, especially forreligiousreasons:nhịn ăn
examples: Muslims fast during Ramadan.
One day a week he fasts for health reasons.
fast[C] a period of time when you eat no food: kì ăn chay; kì ăn kiêng
At the end of their fast, the people have a big party to celebrate.
Hundreds of prisoners began a fast in protest about prison conditions.

children.name: go on hunger strike
children.definition: go on (a) hunger strike if sb goes on a hunger strike, they refuse to eat for days or weeks in order to protest about something or bring public attention to a political problem:tuyệt thực
examples: More than 300 prisoners went on hunger strike in February in protest against the living conditions.
The prisoners havegone on(a) hunger strike to protest about prison conditions.
be on (a) hunger strike
67 men had been on hunger strike since August 13th.
hunger striker[ C ] người tuyệt thực

children.name: be off your food
children.definition: UK especiallyspokenif sb is off their food, they do not want to eat, for example because they feel sick or ill:bỏ ăn vì bệnh
examples: What’s wrong with Billy? He seems to be off his food.
to not want to eat, usually because you are ill

children.name: to eat a lot or too much
gorge yourself
children.definition: stuff/  informal to eat so much food that you cannot eat anything else:ngốn
examples: stuff/gorge yourself with
They'd been stuffing themselveswithsnacks all afternoon, so they didn't want any dinner.
Having stuffed himself with burgers, Terry was unable to finish his dessert.
stuff/gorge yourself on
The Romans would gorge themselves on grapes and plums.

children.name: pig out
children.definition: informal to eat a lot of food - used humorously: ăn như heo
examples: Last night we pigged out and ate three pizzas.
pig out on
When he’s depressed he always pigs out on ice cream.
We pigged outonall the lovely cakes and pastries.

children.name: make a pig of yourself
children.definition: informal disapproving to eat too much food - used especially humorously, and used to say that sb has behaved in an embarrassing way when eating with other people: ăn uống vô độ
examples: I had four pieces of cake and made a real pig of myself.
Don’t make such a pig of yourself; you’ve eaten enough.
They made complete pigs of themselves at the dinner.

children.name: overeat
children.definition: to regularly eat too much in a way that is bad for your health:ăn nhiều
examples: You need to watch your weight - have you been overeating?
A woman who overeats during pregnancy can cause health problems for her child.
overeating[U]
We’re constantly being reminded of the dangers of overeating.

children.name: sb who enjoys eating a lot
big eater
children.definition: a big/ good eater sb who usually eats a lot of food:người ăn khỏe
examples: Don’t give me such a large portion. I’m not a big eater.
What can I cook for them? They’re such big eaters.

children.name: gourmet
children.definition: sb who knows a lot about food and drink and likes good quality food and drink:người sành ăn
examples: They’re real gourmets and buy only the best cuts of meat.
Many gourmets say that Camembert should never be kept in a fridge.
gourmet food/ cooking etcvery good and usually expensive
The shop only sells gourmet food, at astronomical prices.

children.name: foodie
children.definition: UKinformalsb who is interested in food, and likes going to restaurants and trying new and unusual foods:người có tâm hồn ăn uống
examples: a new magazine for foodies.
Michael Caine is an avid foodie who owns a string of restaurants.

children.name: to eat small amounts of food
pick at
children.definition: to eat only a small part of a meal, especially because you feelillorunhappy:nhấm nháp
examples: I sat picking at my dinner, wishing I were somewhere else.

children.name: hardly touch sth
children.definition: hardly touch your food/dinner/meal etc informal to eat almost none of your dinner, meal etc:hầu như không động đến
examples: Are you feeling okay? You’ve hardly touched your dinner.
We were so full by the time dessert came that we hardly touched it.
No thanks, I never touch chocolate/alcohol.
Honestly, I haven't toucheda drop(= drunk any alcohol) all night.

children.name: nibble
children.definition: to eat sth by biting very small pieces: nhấm nháp
examples: The horse lowered his head and began to nibble the grass.
He nibbled the biscuit cautiously.
nibble on/ at
We stood around drinking wine and nibbling on little snacks.
He nibbled on a piece of raw carrot.
There’s a fish nibbling at my bait.

children.name: sb who only eats certain types of food
fussy eater
children.definition: be a  to refuse to eat particular types of food and only eat food that you especially like: người kén ăn
examples: All my children were fussy eaters.

children.name: picky eater
children.definition: be a  to refuse to eat particular types of food and only eat food that you especially like:người kén ăn
examples: Stan’s such a picky eater; it’s impossible to know what to cook for him.

children.name: eat up
children.definition: to eat all of sth and not leave anything:ăn hết
examples: eat up sth
Come on, boys -- eat up your supper and get to bed.
Be a good boy and eat up your vegetables.
eat sth/it/them up
Margaret ate it all up and then asked for more.
We were always taught to eat our vegetables up.

children.name: finish
children.definition: to finish eating sth:ăn xong
examples: Are you finished?
You may not leave the table until you’ve finished your supper.
I finished my lunch, repacked my back pack, and set off again.
Hurry up and finish so we can make the 7 o'clock show.

children.name: finish off
children.definition: /up to finish eating the rest of the food that is still on the plate, in the pan etc:
examples: finish off/up sth
Who finished off the cake that was left after the party?
Can someone finish up these strawberries so I don’t have to throw them away?
finish sth/it/them off/up
Finish those carrots off and you can have dessert.

children.name: polish off
children.definition: to eat everything that is available, with great enjoyment, until there is none left:chén sạch
examples: polish off sth
At dinner he polished off six fudge brownies and then asked for some more.
polish sth/it/them off
If anyone wants more pizza, come and get it before Dan polishes it all off.

children.name: demolish
children.definition: to eat all of sth very quickly - used humorously: “đánh đổ”xử hết
examples: The kids demolished the cake and then ran back outside to play.
I’ve seen Marian demolish a big box of chocolates in one sitting!
Joe demolished an enormous plateful of sausages and chips.

children.name: devour
children.definition: to eat all of sth quickly because you are very hungry:ngấu nghiến
examples: After the tennis match the boys devoured the sandwiches in seconds.
Wendell devoured a large piece of gingerbread, then licked his fingers greedily.

children.name: wolf down
children.definition: informal to eat food quickly and eagerly, especially because you are very hungry or are in a hurry:ngốn, ăn ngấu nghiến
examples: wolf down sth/ wolf sth down
I wolfed down my breakfast but still felt hungry.
They were already late so they wolfed down their lunch and caught the 2.30 train.
When the food finally came she wolfed it down immediately.

children.name: bolt down
children.definition: UK to eat sth too quickly, especially because you are in a hurry:ngốn, ăn ngấu nghiến
examples: bolt down sth/ bolt sth down
He bolted down two hamburgers then washed them down with Coca-Cola.
Don’t bolt your food down! Chew it up slowly.

children.name: gobble down
children.definition: gobble up/down to eat sth quickly and noisily, especially because you are taking a lot of food into your mouth: “tiếng kêu gộp gộp của gà tây”nuốt chửng/ ngấu nghiến
examples: gobble sth up/down
Mike gobbled his lunch down then dashed off to meet his next client.
gobble up/down sth
The cat leapt onto the kitchen counter and gobbled up the smoked salmon intended for dinner.

children.name: scarf
children.definition: scoffUK /US  informal to eat sth very quickly: ngốn, ăn ngấu nghiến
examples: I left three pies in the fridge and someone’s scoffed the lot!
scoff up/down sth
I scoffed down breakfast in my car on the way to work.
scoff sth up/down
Wow, you two really scoffed those cookies up.

children.name: live on sth
children.definition: live onsth to only eat a particular type of food : "sống nhờ vào" chỉ dùng, chỉ ăn
examples: I more or less live on pasta.

children.name: feast on sth
children.definition: feast onsth literary to eat a lot of good food and enjoy it very much: ăn cỗ; ăn tiệc với
examples: We feasted on smoked salmon and champagne.

children.name: cannibal
children.definition: a person who eats human flesh, or an animal which eats the flesh of animals of its own type : kẻ ăn thịt người, thú ăn thịt đồng loại
examples: cannibalism[ U ] tục ăn thịt người; tục ăn thịt đồng loại
cannibalistic[adj]

children.name: sb who always eats very little
small eater
children.definition: a  sb who always eats very little : người ăn yếu
examples: Could she just be asmalleater?
